bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1920

div1.p: Rose describes plans for yellow fever work in West Africa. He also reports on the situation in Mexico and Central America.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1920

July 20, 1920
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am writing to inform you, as a member of
the Yellow Fever Council, that the Board has decided
that the study of the yellow fever situation in West
Africa should be continued, and that immediate steps
should be taken to get a number of promising men in
training, with a view to the final selection of two
of them for this work. The present plan is that a
commission for studying yellow fever be sent to West
Africa to be composed of two epidemiologists, two
bacteriologists, two laboratory assistants and a secre-
tary; that full field equipment should be furnished in
duplicate; that Dakar, Freetown and Lagos should be
used as headquarters.

The 1920 commission recommended that the next
commission to Africa should have on its staff two bac-
Doctor Henry R Carter
July 20, 1921
2.
teriologists, qualified in the laboratory technique
necessary for the diagnosis of the suspected fever or
fevers in Africa. Following this recommendation, plans
are under way for the training of bacteriologists for
this purpose by Doctor Noguchi.

The situation in Mexico and Central America
seems most encouraging. Some cases of yellow fever have
been reported in the past two months in the region about
Tuxpam and from the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. The mosquito
index is low in the principal centers, - Tampico, Tuxpam,
Vera Cruz and Merida. For more than four months no
case has been reported from any of the Central American
countries. Recent reports from Peru indicate a steady
lowering of the mosquito index in northern Peru and a
corresponding fall in case reports. Doctor Hanson and
his staff seem to be getting the situation well in hand.

Doctor Joseph H White obtained a three months
leave of absence from the United States Public Health
Service in order to make a trip of inspection of yellow
fever conditions in Ecuador and Peru. He left New York
on June 11. By this time he should be in Peru.

Doctor White has written us that conditions
with reference to preventive mosquito breeding measures,
are fairly satisfactory in Ecuador. He has recommended
that the Board make an appropriation of $2000 to Doctor
Pareja to assist him in perfecting his campaign.

The decline of the mosquito index and the falling
off of yellow fever cases reported from the various
countries is distinctly encouraging. Those who are
responsible for the work understand, however, the importance
of continuing energetic measures against mosquitoes.
The plan of operations provides for holding the mosquito
index below the danger point for at least a year after
the last reported case of yellow fever.

If at any time you have suggestions to offer con-
cerning the plan of work or methods employed, we shall
welcome your suggestions. It is our intention to keep
you in touch with the progress of the work so that we
may receive from you from time to time the benefit of your
advice.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor Henry R Carter
Care of Mr H C Redd
Ashland
Virginia
